title: graph theory - Does anybody know how to prove or disprove the following guess about edge coloring of Hypergraphs?
body: Definition. Suppose $H=(V,E)$ is a hypergraph. Call a hyperedge $e=\{v_1,v_2,\dotsc,v_k\}$ a $k$ -star if in the 1-skeleton of $H$ there is a copy of $K^{1,k-1}$ whose union equals $e$ . (Obviously in the case $k=2$ , $e$ is an usual edge.) EDITED: Consider the following two properties: (a) For every hyperedge $e$ of $H$ there exists $k\in\mathbb{N}$ such that $e$ is $k$ -star. (b) If two hyperedges $e_i$ and $e_j$ which share at least one vertices ( $|e_i\cap e_j|\geq1$ ) then there is an usual edge that connect internal nodes of this two hyperedges. Question: Does anybody know how to prove or disprove the following guess about edge coloring of Hypergraphs? Let $\Delta(H)$ denote the maximum of vertex-degrees of a finite hypergraph $H$ . Guess. Let $H$ be a simple hypergraph satisfying (a) and (c). Then there exists an $(\Delta+1)$ -edge-coloring so that any two edges which share one vertices have distinct colors. graph-theory graph-colorings hypergraph Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jun 15, 2020 at 7:27 Community Bot 1 2 2 silver badges 3 3 bronze badges asked Apr 4, 2018 at 16:12 C.F.G 4,205 6 6 gold badges 36 36 silver badges 67 67 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 5 $\begingroup$ Dear @C.F.G.: I did a more-or-less complete re-write of your question, because I found it unclear in places. Needless to say, you can re-edit. I don't understand condition (c), and I didn't touch it. Would you please clarify what (c) means? $\endgroup$ Peter Heinig –  Peter Heinig 2018-04-05 07:30:16 +00:00 Commented Apr 5, 2018 at 7:30 $\begingroup$ Dear @PeterHeinig, you know that each hyperedge in this question has one central node ( internal node). the means of condition (c) is that internal nodes of hyperedges are not connected to any leaves of hyperedges and not connected to another internal nodes. $\endgroup$ C.F.G –  C.F.G 2018-04-05 07:51:34 +00:00 Commented Apr 5, 2018 at 7:51 $\begingroup$ thanks for clarifying; however, it is still not clear: the way you defined '$k$-star' and condition (a), the 'internal node' of a hyperedge need not be unique , so (c) is simply undefined . Would you please think about what you are asking and then formulate the question unambiguously? $\endgroup$ Peter Heinig –  Peter Heinig 2018-04-05 11:32:22 +00:00 Commented Apr 5, 2018 at 11:32 $\begingroup$ I have deleted the condition (c) but this is not my wanted. I want an extra condition that says: no central node of a hyperedge coincide with leave node of another hyperedge. $\endgroup$ C.F.G –  C.F.G 2018-04-06 07:21:04 +00:00 Commented Apr 6, 2018 at 7:21 1 $\begingroup$ .: re "I want an extra condition that says: no central node of a hyperedge coincide with leave node of another hyperedge.": this is good to know; I was about to point out that your conditions so far seem to make coloring more difficult, and in particular, for any hypergraph $H$ once can easily 'saturate' $H$ with enough 2-element hyperedges to make (a) and (b) while not lowering the chromatic number. The condition you now mentioned makes more sense, since it seems to edge-coloring easier. By the way, do you allow multiple edges' in your 'hypergraphs"? (some peapole do, some don't.) $\endgroup$ Peter Heinig –  Peter Heinig 2018-04-06 07:33:19 +00:00 Commented Apr 6, 2018 at 7:33 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
